div1.p: Wood provides news of a yellow fever epidemic among American troops.

div1.head: Letter from Leonard Wood to Francis V. Greene, July 12, 1899
div1.opener:
Santiago de Cuba, July 12, 1899
approx
35-
words
2 pp folio
typescript
signed
Headquarters Department of Santiago,
ADJUTANT GENERAL'S OFFICE,
CIVIL DEPARTMENT.
P E R S O N A L
General F. V. Greene.
Lawyers Club.
New York.
Dear General:-
div1.p:
I have just returned and find that the Yellow Fever
epidemic here is confined entirely to the American residents of the
city. The Americans working in your street gangs have escaped; only
one having been taken down thus far. This percentage is much lower
than the general percentage among the American occupants and goes to
prove very conclusively, I think, that the street work has not been
the cause of the epidemic. The troops have all been removed from the
city to safe points inland, points at which Yellow Fever has never
originated. The death rate among the officers has been very heavy;
everyone who has taken it has died. At present it seems to be of a
milder type and for the last five days we have had no new cases among
the troops, and the old cases are all convalescent. Since my arrival
yesterday morning I have been on the jump trying to establish the ab-
solutely necessary measures which should have been established two
weeks ago. (Confidentially), I have been simply horrified to find how
little has been done to check the thing.

The unwashed American element is having a hard time, as I am ar-
resting every American, scrubbing, disinfecting and putting him on a
Gral. Greene. No. 2
disinfected ship in the harbour where, after seven days healthful stay
he will be shipped out of the country willing, or unwilling. I have
tied the whole place up with a cast-iron military order which is
going to cause a great deal of kicking, but which I think will save
a great many lives, and I hope soon to check the spread of the dis-
ease. There sems to be no particular point of infection. The native
doctors are inclined to think that the great heat and unusual drought
are responsible for it. There are no cases among the native popula-
tion and their death rate from other causes are unusually low, in fact
outside the Yellow Fever among our own people, the city is in an un-
usual good state of health.

I saw your nephew yesterday; he is looking well. I have advised
your superintendent that unless the epidemic is promptly checked, we
had better finish up what streets we have open and discontinue work
until the first of October. By that time, I hope we shall have money
enough to do even more work than we contemplated.

With kindest reagrds and thanking you for the very many cour-
tesies which you extended to me during my visit,
